course_title: Exploring Indigenous Art, Film, Music and Literature Through Iconic Works

learning_outcomes.description: Critically reflect on the impact of colonialisation on Indigenous cultural expression in the arts, connecting this reflection to your own positionality and specific disciplinary interests.

Identify an example within your discipline and/or related career aspiration that connects to Indigenous arts, and analyse its significance within broader social, economic, historical, and/or political contexts.
Sensitively communicate your analysis on the ways in which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples use the arts to express life experiences.
Critically evaluate and take a position on current or historical issues, opinions, facts, or statements concerning Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural expression.

assessments.due_date:

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.

Written assessment due in Week 6.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. While students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 1: Comparative Analysis Literature and Music (Written) 

Word Count: 1000

Weight: 40%

(See Blackboard for due date)

Task Description:

For this assessment you will conduct a comparative analysis on the thematic elements in “Am I Black Enough For You? Ten Years On” by Prof. Anita Heiss and one piece of music created by an Indigenous artist. Your analysis should focus on the cultural expressions connected to the social, economic, historical and political context of Indigenous peoples. You are required to include excerpts from the book including page numbers and lyrics from the song. Use APA 7th style for referencing. A minimum of three academic references are required.

Instructions:

1. Read Am I Black Enough For You? Ten Years On by Prof. Anita Heiss

2. Choose a song created by an Indigenous artist or group that you were exposed to in the course or that you are familiar.

3. Provide a brief summary of the book and the song you selected. Explain why you selected the song and how it relates to the book. Make sure to include the historical and cultural context of the song.

4. Explain your positionality and/or standpoint.

5. Discuss how the themes in the book and the song reflect identity, community, resistance and resilience.

6. Analyse how the book and song address social, political, historical and economic experiences facing Indigenous peoples. Consider themes such as activism, and social justice. Discuss any significant differences and what they reveal about the messages being conveyed.

7. Summarise your findings and reflect on the importance of using Indigenous literature and music to express life experiences. Consider what new insights you gained about Indigenous cultural expressions and their social, economic, historical, and political contexts through this comparative study.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 2. Reflection (Written)

Word Count: 500 words

Weight: 20%


Task Description: You are required to write a reflective journal entry on the theme art. You will be given time in the tutorials to complete this task. You are required to write a reflection which summarises your experience attending an art gallery and exploring a piece of art created by an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander person. Please see the instructions below for further information about the reflection. Note that you are required to connect to the content covered in class and/or experienced in class into your reflection. Please use APA 7th edition when you are referencing lecture content and/or tutorial slides.


Instructions for reflections:

1.Personal Experience and Response:

  • Visit an art gallery (could be the one we attend during class or elsewhere) and select one piece of art created by an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander person.
  • Incorporate personal experiences by taking notes about the artwork's visual elements, material, theme and how you connected to the art.

2.Connection to Course Content:

  • Integrate insights from lectures, readings, and class discussions/excursions.

3.Personal Impact and potential professional impact:

  • Discuss how the artwork has influenced your understanding of Indigenous cultures.
  • Reflect on any changes in your perceptions or attitudes.
  • Highlight key insights, personal growth and connection to discipline/career aspirations, if applicable.

4.Use an AI tool to research the artist:

  • Critical analysis - consider how AI-assisted research shaped, challenged or enhanced your understanding of the artist.
  • Was the information generated, correct? If so, how do you know? What did you use to verify the information generated?

5.Summary:

  • Summarise your experience attending the art gallery, selecting the piece of art and integrating AI tools into your assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 3: Analysis of Film (Group Presentation) 

Presentation: Transcript and 10-minute presentation. (Note that the transcript will be due for everyone on Thursday in Week 12. Presentations will take place in class during Week 12 and Week 13. You will be allocated a presentation day. Please refer to Blackboard for more information about the assessment and associated due dates)

Weight: 40%

(See Blackboard for due date)

Task Description:

This is a group assessment. Your group is required to complete an analysis of one scene from a film (your group will be assigned a film). The analysis should focus on the cultural expressions connected to the social, economic, historical, and political contexts of Indigenous peoples. You are required to include the scene (with timestamps) from the film. Use APA 7th style for referencing. A minimum of three academic references are required. You can use a maximum of 5 slides (excluding the title slide and reference list).

Instructions:

1.    Choose a scene from the film created by an Indigenous filmmaker and/or featuring Indigenous actors that your group felt has strong message. Provide a screenshot of the film and/or timestamps.

2.    Provide a brief background of the film and the historical and cultural context of the work you have chosen.

3.    Explain why you selected this scene and how it demonstrates Indigenous cultural expression.

4.    Discuss how the visual elements in the film scene reflect Indigenous cultural expressions. Consider traditional elements such as symbols, language and/or practices. Were visual cues used to convey cultural meaning or connection to Indigenous identity?

5. Summarise your findings and reflect on the importance of visual analysis in understanding Indigenous film. Consider what new insights you gained about Indigenous cultural expression related to social, economic, historical and political contexts.


Guidelines for Assessment 3 submission:

*Note this is a group assessment. Your group will be allocated a specific film to focus on.
